Award.AwardTitle: Support for the 2012 Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide partial support for the 45th Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology to be held in Columbus, Ohio on July 21-24, 2012. The Society for Mathematical Psychology Conference encourages the presentation of research in which mathematical, statistical, or simulation methods play a significant role in the development of hypotheses or the interpretation of experimental results in the behavioral, neural, and cognitive sciences. In addition, accepted research papers focus on theoretical developments clearly relating to substantive issues or methodologies of obvious use in psychology, cognitive science, cognitive neuroscience, and related areas and/or experimental results which bear directly on particular mathematical or simulation models of aspects of human behavior. This year's conference themes include: (1) Neural models of cognition; (2) Modeling with Big Data; and (3) Bayesian methodology in cognitive modeling. Two events will take place on the day prior to the start of the full Society meeting. One is a half-day meeting focusing on the mentoring of women in mathematical psychology. The other is a half-day workshop entitled "Building Human Cognitive Models Using Quantum Probability and Dynamics."

Mathematical psychology brings together social scientists, statisticians, mathematicians, and computer scientists to work on problems critical to behavioral scientists. Much transformational research has come from the mathematical psychology community, including mathematical models of brain function, memory, and decision-making, as well as the introduction of new methods for data analysis. While mathematical models improve our understanding of human behavior and provide formal structures for future scientific exploration, new and better methods for data analysis allow us to derive more accurate and nuanced conclusions from behavioral data. The annual meeting of the Society advances discovery and understanding. It promotes training and learning of new models and methods for analyzing behavioral data. It makes possible the broad dissemination of new findings important in all areas of psychology, as well as economics, political science, and sociology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided partial support for the 45th Annual Meeting of the Society for Mathematical Psychology,  held in Columbus, Ohio from July 21 through July  24, 2012. There were three parallel tracks of talks, as well as poster sessions, over two and a half days. Over 195 scientists from throughout the world attended, and most presented papers on topics using mathematical and computational methods in multiple fields in psychology. The conference included symposia on the topics of big data, mathematical models of neural systems, and nonlinear dynamical systems. Also featured were plenary addresses given by Dr. Roger Ratcliff (Ohio State University) and Dr. Gregor Schoner (Ruhr-Universitaet Bochum). Dr. Charles Kemp (Carnegie Mellon University) was honored with the 2012 William K. Estes Early Career Award. In addition, there were two preconference workshops. One was on Building Human Cognitive Models Using Quantum Probability and Dynamics. The second was a symposium focusing on women in mathematical psychology. The majority of the project award was provided to graduate students  to offset some expenses to attend the conference (cost of registering for the conference) in order to encourage greater student involvement. Additional information about the Society can be found at the following web site: http://www.mathpsych.org.
